bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 30, 1912

div1.p: Agramonte demands that Kean correct the injustice done to him regarding his unfair portrayal in the Yellow Fever Commission. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 30, 1912
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K, ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA.
--
Agramonte
November 30th, 1912.
My dear Colonel:
div1.p:
The following apears on page 92, Yellow-fever Bureau Bulletin,
Vol II No 1 of Liverpool, England:

“Again, Agramonte claims equal credit with the other members of the Commission but
according to various authors, did not take part in the first series of mosquito trans-
mission experiments, nor was he even informed of their being carried out, (Compilat-
ion pp. 16 and 21; Janus p. 64.)”

and as the quotation refering to page 16 of the copilation points to a statement
made by you which, -- based upon I know not what information, -- is certainly far
from the truth as I can readily prove, I beg you very earnestly to communicate with
the Yellow-fever Bureau and kindly endeavor to undo the wrong which, your misinformat-
ion at that time, led you to inflict upon me.

My share in the work of the Army Board is a thing that must be definitely determin-
ed, as it affects not only my material interests, but my reputation as well, since should
it appear that I took no part in the investigation or a very indifferent one, it hard-
ly seems honorable that I should have allowed my name to be associated with those of
my colleagues in all the reports made by the Board.

Knowing you as I do, I am sure you will agree with me in that there was no need
at any time to decry the work of any of those connected with the demonstration in order
to enhance the value of Reed's or Carroll's participation and so long as it was of
interest towards obtaining pension for their widows, I was content to remain passive
and overlook the flagrant injustice; now that the object has been attained, I purpose
not to allow an opportunity to pass unchallenged and if necessary to publish document-
ary evidence that will put me right

It may please you to know that the Academy of Sciences of Paris has awarded the
Bréant Prize to Drs. Finlay Sr. and myself, conjointly, for our work in tropical med.
I may have the pleasure of seeing you during the holidays.
Best regards, and thank you for your action.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Agramonte Lt. Col. J. R. Kean U.S.A.
Washington DC.
